ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments:
Product development
Design thinking, human-centered design
Entrepreneurship as a career path

Technical shop skills
Prototyping

I learned so much about the design process, how to appreciate design, pivot on my own designs, and just a better general mindset about entrepreneurship. That along with Im now trained to use machines in the CEID that will help with future projects.
I learned about design, entrepreneurship, and how to make something.

I gained so many insights about life just from the guests alone, not to mention all the great thought provoking lectures that reframe how to approach a problem and how entrepreneurship works in practice. You gain so many valuable skills relating to making things, problem solving, and thinking about problems deeper than you ever have before.

Learned how to effectively navigate problem identification, product ideation, make critical and difficult design decisions, prototype in a very productive manner, utilize the bountiful resources provided by the CEID and its teaching staff, properly test prototypes and fundamental design facets, and to properly process the feedback and ideas of fellow engineers, among so much more.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths
- flexibility, which allows students to pursue their interests
- diversity of student interests, people from many different majors
- balance between guest speakers and shop time

Weaknesses
- needs more time dedicated to training on machines in the shop

The course strengths include a wide array of guest lecturers that have real world experience and answers to questions you may have about being an entrepreneur. The course is set up for student success, and you will grow as a student and maker if you take this class.
Strengths: Joe is great, Alec is great, classmates are great. Weaknesses: none.

The only improvement I can think of would be to have 1 or 2 more explicit deliverables to keep projects moving along, although it's difficult to have consistent assignments that also aren't pointless with a large variety of projects. But maybe one more deliverable in between the initial report and the final presentations. There are too many strengths to this course to list, but I would highlight all the guest speakers and the timeline given for working on our group projects, as well as having weekly check ins.

This course does a great job in nearly every dimension through its fantastic structure. With varied entrepreneurs and engineers coming to speak almost every week you get a plethora of view points, tips, and information regarding the inner workings of start-ups, design and engineering philosophies, career paths, and even personal growth through the path of entrepreneurship. In the other part of the course, you learn to pitch an idea, work with a team to progress from identifying a problem to coming up with a viable and feasible product solution, design and create many prototypes, take constructive engineering feedback, and present a final prototype product, effectively celebrating a high level of accomplishment after 8 weeks of hard work. the only minor improvement that could be made to this course is allowing a little more than 8 weeks to work on the course project and also prioritizing project work time in class.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, I believe that any student interested in product development - especially physical product development - should apply for this class.

Yes, absolutely. I would say that taking this course with a lighter workload in your other classes is recommended, not because its impossible to succeed if you have a lot of work in other classes, but having extra time to put towards this class is worth it.

Yes, I recommend this course if you can get in. The first half of the semester is learning about design and hearing from guest lecturers. The guest lecturers are actually pretty good. The second half is working on your final project. The workload is a lot but it's fun and if you don't procrastinate, then it's not stressful. There is a final presentation at the end with pizza.
I would highly recommend this course to any student looking to get better at coming up with ideas, making things, collaborating, or learning more about entrepreneurship.

Absolutely! If you're at all interested in getting truly hands-on with engineering and design projects you should totally take this course. Don't wait until your senior year to take this course, take it now! I do not see a scenario in which anyone wouldn't immensely enjoy this course.
